THE TRACK SQUAD

VIRGINIA WINS HOMEWOOD MEET
Five Records Fall During the Contest.
Black and Blue Team Victims
of Hard Luck.

The South Atlantic Intercollegiate Track Meet was held at Homewood on Saturday and resulted in
a victory for the University of Virginia with 45 points. Johns Hopkins was a close second with 38%
points. The other teams ranked behind these as follows: Virginia Polytechnic Institute, Georgetown University, University of North Carolina, Agricultural and Mechanical
College of North Carolina and
Washington and Lee University.
Maxson of Virginia was dile individual star, winning three first
places. Dignan of Hopkins and
Cronly of Virginia were tied for
second honors with io points each.
Horrax of Hopkins won nine points.
Wagner and Lee, both of Hopkins,
and Legge of Virginia Polytechnic
Institute were equal as regards
fifth honors, each one having six
points.
Five records were broken during
the meet. In the 440-yard dash
Stebbins of Georgetown encircled
the track in 50 seconds; the former

record was 5W5 seconds. Cooke
of the University of Virgina in the
half-mile ran away from his competitors and made the distance in
minute 583/5 seconds., beating the
record made last year of 2 minutes
13/s seconds. Gantt of Virginia won
the two-mile run in io minutes II
seconds, which is almost 30 seconds
faster than the former record. The
time of the 220-yard hurdles was
cut down two-fifths of a second by
Cronly of Virginia. The relay team
from Virginia broke the former record held by two Hopkins teams. Another record would have b e en
broken, that for the 12o---yard
hurdles. Cronly covered the ground
in 153/5 seconds, which beats the
record time made last year by Horrax, but Cronly kicked over one
hurdle, so his time cannot go as a
record.
The Johns Hopkins team had
hard luck throughout the meet. On
Friday McDonagh, who had been
counted on to place in the 220-yard
dash and 220-yard hurdles, was running the 220-yard hurdles and was
in the lead until almost the end.
Here he fell and skinned his knee.
His knee troubled him in the 220(continued on page 5, col. 3.)

THE SENIOR WEEK COMMITTEE

CARLISLE DEFEATS VARSITY

Arrangements Made to See After Different Forms of Entertainment—All
Classes Invited to Participate.

The Johns Hopkins Lacrosse Team Loses
First Game of Season Championship Is Still in Doubt.

Like all perfect things the sojourn
of the Class of 1913 at Hopkins
must come to an end. The date of
its passing out "from its alma mater
far, far in the wide, wide, wide
world" is set for June io. But what
of the preeeding weck ? For that
period the 1913 Senior Week Committee is arranging to give a supreme proof in one short week to
typify the brilliant record which the
class has made during the last four
years in all college activities. It has
begun to make arrangements for a
Senior Week which—well, in short
—will be in keeping with everything
else the Class of 1913 has donç.,
To begin to outline plans for such
a week the Senior Week Committee had its first meeting on last
Wednesday at one o'clock. No definite plan could be formulated at
this organization meeting. Several
special committees were appointed
to inquire into the feasibility and the
expense of several different forms
Aof entertainment suggested by mem-

For the seventh time in as many
games the Hopkins lacrosse team
upset all calculations and suffered
its first defeat. The Carlisle Inlians caused the trouble. They came
up fresh from a- trouncing by the
Navy to meet a team which had tied
the Middies and beaten other teams
which had proved too strong for the
lads from Annapolis, and the Redskins won 4 to 2. Just why, no one
seems to know. Without doubt, the
loss of Sutton and Troxell from the
line-up was severely felt, but Troxell was out against Lehigh, and Hasson played a fine game at point.
Every sort of team is sometimes subject to a slump in spite of all the
coaches can do, and that is probably
what happened to the Black • and
Blue last Saturday. The silver lining to the cloud is that it was not
a championship game, and we still
have a good chance for the banner.
The game itself was interesting
to watch and was not marred by the
slightest dirty playing. The Indians

H. Findlay French, '07, is secretary of the Baltimore Board of
Trade, with offices in the Continental Trust Building.
Donald K. Belt, A. B. '12, has
given up his reportorial position
with the Baltimore News and is now
with William G. Scarlett & Co.,
wholesale seed dealers.
Le Grand W. Perce, A. B. '08, is
at present accompanying a youthful
Washingtonian in a trip around the
world. Perce has left his Chicago
real estate business in the hands of
his brother, as he expects to be gone
almost a year and a half.
Charles K. Winne, A. B. '97, M.
announces the birth of a son,
D.
Charles Merrill Winne, on April 27,
1913. Mrs. Winie is a graduate of
the Johns Hopkins Hospital Training School for Nurses. The baby
has already been placed on the
Homewood waiting list.
After several months in America,
Thomas G. Machen, A. B. '05, has
left again for Paris, where he will
complete the architectural studies
which he has pursued in Europe for
about five years. Probably in six
months Mr. Machen will return to
practice his profession in New York.

Thomas R. Brown, A. B. '92, M.
D. '96, president of the Alumni Association, is associate in medicine at
the Johns Hopkins Hospital, as well
as being in charge of the gastrointestinal clinic. While in the University, Dr. Brown was extremely
Popular and was class president during his senior year. He spent the
last year studying abroad. Dr.
Brown is also the author of numerous medical articles.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 5, 1913.
Honor to Whom Honor is Due.

Throughout the present academic
year we have been hearing and reading letters, editorials, appeals for
support, encouraging news and humorous comment regarding the Hullabaloo for 1913. For a time the
whole student body was stirred up
and excited over getting pictures
taken for class pictures, board pictures, fraternity pictures and team
pictures, until it seemed to some that
the Hullabaloo would be a sort of
photographic supplement to t h e
Class of 1913. At the present time,
however, all the agony and boosting
are over, and the University is
awaiting the publication of the
much-heralded book. The proof
sheets have been received from the
printer and within a few weeks the
bound volumes will be distributed.
Too much cannot be said in commendation of the men who have
worked to produce an annual worthy
of our college; the men who have
spent time, money and hard work
in getting material together, prodding lazy writers, getting advertisements and arranging for details in
actual printing. It is to the editorial
and business staff of the Hullabaloo,
rather than to the Class of 1913,
that credit is chiefly due for the publication of a first-class year hook.
Fil'st among these is Mr. Julian
D. Sears, editor-in-chief, who has
untirino,in his efforts and enbeen untiring
the very best work
thusiasm to
and obtain the very best contributions from the associate editors and
outside Writers. He it was who
kept up interest when it seemed almost impossible that the Hullabaloo
could be revived this _year. Mr.J.Edward Richardson, Jr., too, deserves
the greatest praise for the businesslike way in which he has handled
the finances of the Hullabaloo.

Hot Water.

Again is heard the wail, "No
hot water." In spite of many complaints (unanswered) there is always a scarcity of of hot water for
the athletic teams, both in the cage
and at Homewood. Sometimes it
is the Poly or the City College team
that uses it all, sometimes it is another team that has gone before,
but there is never enough. Teams
which practice hard hate, when the
practice is over, to have their
muscles and joints tortured by icy
deluges. We can only pray the
powers that be to look down upon
us and have mercy.

BALTIMORE

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

SIR—My -attention has been called
to an article which appears in this
week's issue of Tilt NEWS-LETTER,
registering a cdmplaint against the
raising of subscriptions for the purpose of sending a member of the
track and field team to the University of Pennsylvania relay carnival,
and charging that the management
of the track and field team is not
properly equipping the candidates.
To the first of these charges, I
would like to reply that any subscriptions which have been made or
which will be made in the future
have been unauthorized by the management and that they are made
without the consent and with the
disapproval of those in charge of
the affairs of the team, and it is the
desire, when such requests are made,
that they be rejected.
In regard to equipment, those men
who are entitled to various forms of
equipment and who, in the opinion
of the management, deserve to be
supplied from the funds of the Athletic Association have been given the
necessities. The track and field
team is as well, if not better,
equipped this year than ever before.
Because of the heavy expense the
team is under, due largely to the
interscholastic meet, which is a direct loss, it is impossible to give
every member of the squad full
equipment.
At the present time the finances of
the team are in better condition than
has been the case for several years,
and the indications are that instead
of a large deficit, which has been
the custom in many previous years,
there will be a small surplus.
Very truly yours,
PAUL 0. CARTER,
Manager Track and Field Team.

THE NEWS—LETTER, MAY 5, 1913.
WELL-BALANCED PENN TEAM WINS

VIRGINIA WINS HOMEWOOD MEET

THE CLASSICAL ASSOCIATION

(Continuedfrom page 1.)

Seventh Annual Meeting Held at McCoy
Hall—Addresses by Well-Known
Lovers of the Classics.

Friday
In Tennis Match at Homewood on
Matches
Straight
Six
Takes
It
From Johns Hopkins.

On Friday afternoon commenced
the seventh annual meeting of the
Classical Association of the Atlantic
States. Dr. Welch, chairman of the
Administrative Committee, opened
the meeting with an address of welcome. Dr. B. W. Mitchell, president of the association, spoke in
reply. Later Dr. Magoffin gave an
illustrated talk entitled "A Day in
the Roman Campagna," and Dr.
Bennett of Union College made an
appeal to teachers of Latin to support Greek, with definite suggestions
of ways in which that support can be
made effective. The other speakers
on Friday were Dr. Max Radin and
Dr. Florence M. Bennett, both of
New York.
Friday evening at 7.30 o'clock a
banquet was held in the Donovan
Room. Dr. Kirby Smith read a
paper entitled:"Vergil in the Middle
Ages." Saturday morning papers
were read by Professor Ebeling of
Goucher College, Dr. Gildersleeve,
Dr. Lee of Philadelphia and Dr.
McDaniel of the University of Pennsylvania. After a luncheon at one
o'clock on Saturday, more papers
dealing with the Classics were read.

The University of Pennsylvania
tennis team proved too strong for
Hopkins in the tournament on Friday. Last year the score was 4 to 2
in favor of Penn, but this year
Hopkins did not get a match; the
final result being 6 to a However,
in 1913 the Philadelphians have
been reinforced by two exceptional
players in A. \V. Jones and A. E.
Kennedy. Jones is an Australian
who has defeated in his time several
members of the Australian international players, and Kennedy is the
present holder of the Rhode Island
singles championship.
Next week Hopkins will play two
matches away from home: on Wednesday at Annapolis with St. John's
and on Saturday with Catholic University in Washington. Catholic
University has already this season
easily beaten St. John's.
The Maryland Chapter of the Phi
Beta Kappa held its annual dinner
on Saturday evening in the Donovan Room. Talcott Williams, director of Columbia's School of
Journalism was the orator.

four hurdles and was disqualified.
Lloyd, in the 440-yard dash, picked
one of the last numbers and was
obliged to start behind the line. He
had difficulty in getting through
those before him.
Freddie Lee "came back" in the
mile run. He took the lead at the
start and kept it till the finish, beating the second man (Patterson) by
a good margin. In the two-mile
run Lee and Reeside kept first place
for about the first mile, then both
fell back, but Lee spurted at the end
and made fourth place. In two of
the heats of the 880-yard run on
Friday Hopkins men (Catlin and
Uhler) took first places. Cooke led
the third heat. In the finals Catlin
kept the lead for the first quarter,
but Cooke shot past and won at
the stretch. The fast pace that Catlin set told on him and he was
obliged to fall out. Uhler ended
among the leaders and barely failed
to place. The pole vault was hotly
contested. Horrax took first place
by clearing the bar on his third vault.

THE NEWS-LETTER, MAY 5, 1913.
THE NEWS-LETTER'S MAIL BAG
A Column in Which the Correspondents
Are Allowed Latitude, but Shoulder the Responsibility.
The Athletic Policy.

May 2, 1913.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
My silence on res Hopkinsienses
since, last year emboldens me to
crave space now to criticise what
I believe to be a censurable athletic policy, namely, the penury with
which the track team is being treated. It is true that whatever attitude may be adopted by the Athletic Association or the management
is none of my business, but the
questions involved are such that
they can hardly be discussed by the
team members who have suffered,
and as publicity can certainly do no
harm, but on the contrary may do a
great deal of good, I venture to be
the one to write a letter which will
voice the sentiments of many.
The Armory meet, in which the
interests of the University were
looked after by the track athletic
management, netted more than ever
before. The exact figures were not
announced, but the gain was at least
one or two hundred dollars. This
does not go to the credit of the track
team, but to a separate account..
Such a disposal is, of course, merely
a.matter of bookkeeping, but it certainly seems fair that the track
squad should get some of the benefits of the extra money. Up to the
present they haven't.
The candidates are compelled to
furnish practically the whole of their
equipment. Some material, it is
true, is bought for the graduate and
medical students, but undergraduates who are not in such circumstances that they can afford to purchase expensive spiked shoes or
other articles have, if they wish to.
run as well as possible, been compelled to furnish the appurtenances.
Economy is under all circumstances much to be desired, but
there is such a thing as a policy of
inconsistent closeness which is decidedly objectionable. Every football man last season was furnished
with a complete outfit to the smallest
detail. With the exception of
gloves, this has been true of the
baseball team. It was at first proposed that this year the lacrosse men
would have to •purchase their own
sticks, but the entirely proper stand
of the coaches caused a change.
Sticks are a necessity for lacrosse;
sharp spikes are only a convenience
for track work, and there the men
who, due, in an as yet unrecognized
degree, to the efforts of Mr. Joseph
*I ownsend England, have turned out
the best team that Hopkins has ever
had in any sport, with the exception
of lacrosse, are at a disadvantage.
Efficiency has been sacrificed to an
unwise retrenchment, and men, to
whom it came hard, have been compelled, in whole or in part, to buy
their own outfit.
With such a team as we have this
year, the wish that it should be
pushed ought not to be in vain

And yet one man who can do the
hundred in record time, and another
who can high jump with the best,
weren't sent to Philadelphia to enter the Pennsylvania games. "Not
enough money" was the reason
given, but in view of the Armory
surplus it seems an inadequate one.
Here was a chance for Hopkins to
place in events against the best intercollegiate athletes in the country;
a chance which it has never had before, and may not have again. The
opportunity was lost.
To conclude, there seems to be no
valid reason for not treating the
track team on a parity with other
teams in the matter of equipment,
and this hasn't been done. When
more money than ever before was
netted on the Armory games, there
seems to be no sufficient reason for
not giving certain of our athletes,
who are among the best in the country, a chance to show their ability
and advertise Hppkins sports in
meets against other colleges. Another opportunity on May 30 and
31 will be offered by the Northern
Intercollegiates, to be held at Boston. Every Hopkins man who
seems likely to be able to place
should be sent.
I am aware that this criticism is
based upon second-hand information, and it is, therefore, a criticism
of conditions, not those who are responsible for them, for who they
are, I don't know. If I have made
any misstatements, I will gladly
welcome corrections. These, it is
to be hoped, if forthcoming, will
put the policy maintained toward the
track team in a more favorable
light. I am, sir,
LINDSAY ROGERS.

Dr. William H. Welch of the
Johns Hopkins University w a s
elected president of the National
Academy of Sciences at the closing session of the organization's fiftieth annual meeting held in Washington on Thursday, April 24. Ten
American scientists were elected to
membership. The Academy numbers among its members the foremost scientists of the country.
Charles D. Walcott, secretary of the
Smithsonian Institution was elected
vice-president, and Arthur L. Day
of the Carnegie Institute was elected
secretary. The annual meeting
closed with a banquet at which VicePresident M arshall and Ambassador Bryce were the chief speakers.
The next anniversary meeting will
be held in Atlanta during the first
part of next year.

THE TRACK SQUAD

VIRGINIA WINS HOMEWOOD MEET
Five Records Fall During the Contest.
Black and Blue Team Victims
of Hard Luck.

The South Atlantic Intercollegiate Track Meet was held at Homewood on Saturday and resulted in
a victory for the University of Virginia with 45 points. Johns Hopkins was a close second with 38%
points. The other teams ranked behind these as follows: Virginia Polytechnic Institute, Georgetown University, University of North Carolina, Agricultural and Mechanical
College of North Carolina and
Washington and Lee University.
Maxson of Virginia was dile individual star, winning three first
places. Dignan of Hopkins and
Cronly of Virginia were tied for
second honors with io points each.
Horrax of Hopkins won nine points.
Wagner and Lee, both of Hopkins,
and Legge of Virginia Polytechnic
Institute were equal as regards
fifth honors, each one having six
points.
Five records were broken during
the meet. In the 440-yard dash
Stebbins of Georgetown encircled
the track in 50 seconds; the former

record was 5W5 seconds. Cooke
of the University of Virgina in the
half-mile ran away from his competitors and made the distance in
minute 583/5 seconds., beating the
record made last year of 2 minutes
13/s seconds. Gantt of Virginia won
the two-mile run in io minutes II
seconds, which is almost 30 seconds
faster than the former record. The
time of the 220-yard hurdles was
cut down two-fifths of a second by
Cronly of Virginia. The relay team
from Virginia broke the former record held by two Hopkins teams. Another record would have b e en
broken, that for the 12o---yard
hurdles. Cronly covered the ground
in 153/5 seconds, which beats the
record time made last year by Horrax, but Cronly kicked over one
hurdle, so his time cannot go as a
record.
The Johns Hopkins team had
hard luck throughout the meet. On
Friday McDonagh, who had been
counted on to place in the 220-yard
dash and 220-yard hurdles, was running the 220-yard hurdles and was
in the lead until almost the end.
Here he fell and skinned his knee.
His knee troubled him in the 220(continued on page 5, col. 3.)

else the Class of 1913 has donç.,

this organization meeting. Several
special committees were appointed
to inquire into the feasibility and the
expense of several different forms

upset all calculations and suffered
its first defeat. The Carlisle Inlians caused the trouble. They came
up fresh from a- trouncing by the
Navy to meet a team which had tied
the Middies and beaten other teams
which had proved too strong for the
lads from Annapolis, and the Redskins won 4 to 2. Just why, no one
seems to know. Without doubt, the
loss of Sutton and Troxell from the
line-up was severely felt, but Troxell was out against Lehigh, and Hasson played a fine game at point.
Every sort of team is sometimes subject to a slump in spite of all the
coaches can do, and that is probably
what happened to the Black • and
Blue last Saturday. The silver lining to the cloud is that it was not
a championship game, and we still
have a good chance for the banner.
The game itself was interesting
to watch and was not marred by the

Throughout the present academic
year we have been hearing and reading letters, editorials, appeals for
support, encouraging news and humorous comment regarding the Hullabaloo for 1913. For a time the
whole student body was stirred up
and excited over getting pictures
taken for class pictures, board pictures, fraternity pictures and team
pictures, until it seemed to some that
the Hullabaloo would be a sort of
photographic supplement to t h e
Class of 1913. At the present time,
however, all the agony and boosting
are over, and the University is
awaiting the publication of the
much-heralded book. The proof
sheets have been received from the
printer and within a few weeks the
bound volumes will be distributed.
Too much cannot be said in commendation of the men who have
worked to produce an annual worthy
of our college; the men who have
spent time, money and hard work
in getting material together, prodding lazy writers, getting advertisements and arranging for details in
actual printing. It is to the editorial
and business staff of the Hullabaloo,
rather than to the Class of 1913,
that credit is chiefly due for the publication of a first-class year hook.
Fil'st among these is Mr. Julian
D. Sears, editor-in-chief, who has
untirino,in his efforts and enbeen untiring
the very best work
thusiasm to
and obtain the very best contributions from the associate editors and
outside Writers. He it was who
kept up interest when it seemed almost impossible that the Hullabaloo
could be revived this _year. Mr.J.Edward Richardson, Jr., too, deserves
the greatest praise for the businesslike way in which he has handled
the finances of the Hullabaloo.

BALTIMORE

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

SIR—My -attention has been called
to an article which appears in this
week's issue of Tilt NEWS-LETTER,
registering a cdmplaint against the
raising of subscriptions for the purpose of sending a member of the
track and field team to the University of Pennsylvania relay carnival,
and charging that the management
of the track and field team is not
properly equipping the candidates.
To the first of these charges, I
would like to reply that any subscriptions which have been made or
which will be made in the future
have been unauthorized by the management and that they are made
without the consent and with the
disapproval of those in charge of
the affairs of the team, and it is the
desire, when such requests are made,
that they be rejected.
In regard to equipment, those men
who are entitled to various forms of
equipment and who, in the opinion
of the management, deserve to be
supplied from the funds of the Athletic Association have been given the
necessities. The track and field
team is as well, if not better,
equipped this year than ever before.
Because of the heavy expense the
team is under, due largely to the
interscholastic meet, which is a direct loss, it is impossible to give
every member of the squad full
equipment.
At the present time the finances of
the team are in better condition than
has been the case for several years,
and the indications are that instead
of a large deficit, which has been
the custom in many previous years,
there will be a small surplus.
Very truly yours,
PAUL 0. CARTER,
Manager Track and Field Team.

WELL-BALANCED PENN TEAM WINS

VIRGINIA WINS HOMEWOOD MEET

THE CLASSICAL ASSOCIATION

(Continuedfrom page 1.)

Seventh Annual Meeting Held at McCoy
Hall—Addresses by Well-Known
Lovers of the Classics.

Friday
In Tennis Match at Homewood on
Matches
Straight
Six
Takes
It
From Johns Hopkins.

On Friday afternoon commenced
the seventh annual meeting of the
Classical Association of the Atlantic
States. Dr. Welch, chairman of the
Administrative Committee, opened
the meeting with an address of welcome. Dr. B. W. Mitchell, president of the association, spoke in
reply. Later Dr. Magoffin gave an
illustrated talk entitled "A Day in
the Roman Campagna," and Dr.
Bennett of Union College made an
appeal to teachers of Latin to support Greek, with definite suggestions
of ways in which that support can be
made effective. The other speakers
on Friday were Dr. Max Radin and
Dr. Florence M. Bennett, both of
New York.
Friday evening at 7.30 o'clock a
banquet was held in the Donovan
Room. Dr. Kirby Smith read a
paper entitled:"Vergil in the Middle
Ages." Saturday morning papers
were read by Professor Ebeling of
Goucher College, Dr. Gildersleeve,
Dr. Lee of Philadelphia and Dr.
McDaniel of the University of Pennsylvania. After a luncheon at one
o'clock on Saturday, more papers
dealing with the Classics were read.

The University of Pennsylvania
tennis team proved too strong for
Hopkins in the tournament on Friday. Last year the score was 4 to 2
in favor of Penn, but this year
Hopkins did not get a match; the

in 1913 the Philadelphians have

players in A. \V. Jones and A. E.

who has defeated in his time several
members of the Australian international players, and Kennedy is the
present holder of the Rhode Island
singles championship.

matches away from home: on Wednesday at Annapolis with St. John's
and on Saturday with Catholic University in Washington. Catholic
University has already this season
easily beaten St. John's.
The Maryland Chapter of the Phi

on Saturday evening in the Donovan Room. Talcott Williams, director of Columbia's School of

kept the lead for the first quarter,

THE NEWS-LETTER, MAY 5, 1913.
THE NEWS-LETTER'S MAIL BAG
A Column in Which the Correspondents
Are Allowed Latitude, but Shoulder the Responsibility.
The Athletic Policy.

May 2, 1913.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
My silence on res Hopkinsienses
since, last year emboldens me to
crave space now to criticise what
I believe to be a censurable athletic policy, namely, the penury with
which the track team is being treated. It is true that whatever attitude may be adopted by the Athletic Association or the management
is none of my business, but the
questions involved are such that
they can hardly be discussed by the
team members who have suffered,
and as publicity can certainly do no
harm, but on the contrary may do a
great deal of good, I venture to be
the one to write a letter which will
voice the sentiments of many.
The Armory meet, in which the
interests of the University were
looked after by the track athletic
management, netted more than ever
before. The exact figures were not
announced, but the gain was at least
one or two hundred dollars. This
does not go to the credit of the track
team, but to a separate account..
Such a disposal is, of course, merely
a.matter of bookkeeping, but it certainly seems fair that the track
squad should get some of the benefits of the extra money. Up to the
present they haven't.
The candidates are compelled to
furnish practically the whole of their
equipment. Some material, it is
true, is bought for the graduate and
medical students, but undergraduates who are not in such circumstances that they can afford to purchase expensive spiked shoes or
other articles have, if they wish to.
run as well as possible, been compelled to furnish the appurtenances.
Economy is under all circumstances much to be desired, but
there is such a thing as a policy of
inconsistent closeness which is decidedly objectionable. Every football man last season was furnished
with a complete outfit to the smallest
detail. With the exception of
gloves, this has been true of the
baseball team. It was at first proposed that this year the lacrosse men
would have to •purchase their own
sticks, but the entirely proper stand
of the coaches caused a change.
Sticks are a necessity for lacrosse;
sharp spikes are only a convenience
for track work, and there the men
who, due, in an as yet unrecognized
degree, to the efforts of Mr. Joseph
*I ownsend England, have turned out
the best team that Hopkins has ever
had in any sport, with the exception
of lacrosse, are at a disadvantage.
Efficiency has been sacrificed to an
unwise retrenchment, and men, to
whom it came hard, have been compelled, in whole or in part, to buy
their own outfit.
With such a team as we have this
year, the wish that it should be
pushed ought not to be in vain

And yet one man who can do the
hundred in record time, and another
who can high jump with the best,
weren't sent to Philadelphia to enter the Pennsylvania games. "Not
enough money" was the reason
given, but in view of the Armory
surplus it seems an inadequate one.
Here was a chance for Hopkins to
place in events against the best intercollegiate athletes in the country;
a chance which it has never had before, and may not have again. The
opportunity was lost.
To conclude, there seems to be no
valid reason for not treating the
track team on a parity with other
teams in the matter of equipment,
and this hasn't been done. When
more money than ever before was
netted on the Armory games, there
seems to be no sufficient reason for
not giving certain of our athletes,
who are among the best in the country, a chance to show their ability
and advertise Hppkins sports in
meets against other colleges. Another opportunity on May 30 and
31 will be offered by the Northern
Intercollegiates, to be held at Boston. Every Hopkins man who
seems likely to be able to place
should be sent.
I am aware that this criticism is
based upon second-hand information, and it is, therefore, a criticism
of conditions, not those who are responsible for them, for who they
are, I don't know. If I have made
any misstatements, I will gladly
welcome corrections. These, it is
to be hoped, if forthcoming, will
put the policy maintained toward the
track team in a more favorable
light. I am, sir,
LINDSAY ROGERS.

Dr. William H. Welch of the
Johns Hopkins University w a s
elected president of the National
Academy of Sciences at the closing session of the organization's fiftieth annual meeting held in Washington on Thursday, April 24. Ten
American scientists were elected to
membership. The Academy numbers among its members the foremost scientists of the country.
Charles D. Walcott, secretary of the
Smithsonian Institution was elected
vice-president, and Arthur L. Day
of the Carnegie Institute was elected
secretary. The annual meeting
closed with a banquet at which VicePresident M arshall and Ambassador Bryce were the chief speakers.
The next anniversary meeting will
be held in Atlanta during the first
part of next year.
